ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Course was intended to be self-organizing, which is appropriate. However, theprofessor did not facilitate self-organization at all and, as a result, the class felt completely disorganized and like a waste of time.
The readings were useful to the course, but weren't discussed as much as could have been helpful during class.
The policy sciences framework is incredibly important to large scale conservation efforts. The concepts were great.
The policy science framework is super useful for students who are interested in environment policy and decision making.The case study was helpful to understand the concepts

Going to Yellowstone and applying the policy sciences framework to a real/current case was the most memorable/helpful part of this class. This class got me to think in a new way and see large scale conservation in a totally new light. The reason I came back to graduate school was so that I could transcend my current level of thinking/way of seeing the world, and this class definitely helped me accomplish that. This was an eye-opening, life-changing class for me. I also really enjoyed the various guest speakers who came in to speak to the class. It was very helpful to hear from professionals out in the field who are applying the policy sciences framework in their own work.

This course has fundamentally changed the way I think about conservation and how I will engage in work from this point forward. It is rare to find such a course, and I am thrilled to have had the opportunity. The material is challenging and requires thought and reflection; it is possible to understand the material and process it in the classroom, but it is only in the field, working on actual problems and questions that the material really settles in and reveals itself. Taking the course for 6 credits afforded me the opportunity to travel to Yellowstone and adopt a case study to apply the material. The 8 days in Montana alone has informed my thinking more than any other course I have taken here thus far.
The policy sciences provides a very useful framework for policy students.
The group work as a way to discuss ideas in greater depth. The guest speakers were excellent.
innovative thinking
Subject matter was very interesting and helpful. This was probably one of the most useful classes I will take at Yale due to its applicability to problem-solving.
Student discussions and field trips

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The organization was horrendous
The course seemed disorganized. There is a difference between a flexible plan and a disorganized course. This course felt disorganized.
It is better for the professor to provide more explicit guidance on case study.
unorganized - the concept of a student-led class is valuable, but it still requires organization on the professor's part.

The lectures were not always easy to follow/sit through, and the Powerpoint presentations were often way too long. I would have really appreciated having more time dedicated to group discussions. I met with students outside of class to discuss the material, and it was incredibly helpful and fun. More in-class discussions would help students learn/understand the material better. I also found it frustrating that for the Last Green Valley group work we were stuck in the same groups the entire semester. I was under the impression that we would be switching groups so that we would could learn more about social, decision, and biophysical processes. I didn't like that I had to stick with one process and one group the whole semester (I felt I was missing out on the other processes) and that this semester planwasn't made explicit early on in the semester.

This course is a difficult one to teach I suspect because the material is not concrete or fixed; instead it challenges the students to re-think their approach and provides a framework for equipping students with the skills to improve their analytical approaches to conservation questions. Students approach the course from a diversity of skill-levels and experiences though and enter at different starting points. This is not a mechanistic framework, but rather requiresactive and willing participation from students. All of this presents difficulties in teaching the material.
Focus. It was too much to cover two separate case studies. A focus on one or the other I think would have been more meaningful.
Organization. The case study was barely organized and many things should have happened earlier in the semester.
The course would benefit from the incorporation of readings into class discussions, more discussions overall, and a more open environment for challenging the material that is presented.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Great
They made themselves very available. Useful conversations one-on-one.

I contacted both the instructor and TA and both were always responsive and available. I didn't always get a clear answer, but they definitely took the time to interact and speak with anyone who had questions.

Both the TA and instructor were extremely available to the students. I had many conversations with the instructor outside of the classroom and these were some of the more valuable educational moments of the semester for me. Availability to students is a priority for this instructor, which is not always the case for professors here at school.
Susan was very available and responded quickly to email and requests to meet.
The professor provided help when asked.
I love Susan. She is always helpful and inspiring.
Excellent, the professor always made time for students to discuss and brainstorm.
Both the instructor and TA were open and available to students - more so than in other classes. Students could choose to take advantage of this or not.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I returned to grad school to further explore human-nature relationships so this class is extremely relevant to me and my professional career. All environmental managers should take this class regardless of whether they are studying wildlife or not. The topics discussed in this class are inherent to any type of resource-management issue.

I am most interested in landscape scale conservation in my work here at FES, so this course was a logical and natural fit. I have been here at FES to try to develop a broad and diverse set of knowledges and skills to apply to work the necessitates the integration of a wide range of perspectives, knowledges, and disciplines. This course has provided with a framework for thinking about how to understand and think about the conservation problems that most interest me. This course will inform all of my future academic and professional work.
Pertinent. It allowed me to connect the dots
The way of thinking helped me a lot
Perfect for a policy background focused student. For myself, it was therefore perfect.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn more about how science, policy, and management are used in conjunction to achieve sustainability at large scales. I wanted to learn how to be an effective resource manager and I also really wanted to go to Yellowstone.
I am most interested in studying landscape level conservation, so this course is one I have been looking forward to since I enrolled here.
I wanted to take a class with Susan. I was hoping to find a framework to use when analyzing policy. I found that here.
Im interested in large scale conservation.
I want to work in conservation.
Interest in the subject and the professor.
I took this course to build upon my experience and understanding of large scale conservation.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: no
Yes
No.

The Yellowstone trip/discussions/work part of the class exceeded my expectations and ended up being the highlight of my spring semester at FES. The Last Green Valley part of the class was disappointing and frustrating.

This course was excellent, and exceeded my expectations. I thought this course would be extremely valuable to my academic preparations here and to all my future professional work. However, this course has fundamentally shifted how I think about conservation, greatly deepening my understanding of what conservation means and how I want to go about pursuing my work. This course gave me the skills and framework to articulate many of my thoughts that have been hanging out at the periphery of my thoughts; it challenged my thinking, caused my to reflect on how I approach my work and life even, and has pushed my thinking beyond what it has been to this point.
Yes.
No. too many slide shows. Not sufficient discussion.
No. The course felt disorganized and little was done to address different challenges in large scale conservation.
Yes, but we should do our field trip earlier.
Yes
Not entirely.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: no
Yes
No.
Yes.
This course was excellent, and I got more than I expected from it. See question 17 above.
Yes.
no. I wish we could have done more case studies.
Not really. I would have liked to have a greater variety of case studies or a better in-depth effort.
Yes
I definitely got more out of the field trips than I had anticipated, and I feel like I was able to get something valuable out of the class and overall experience.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: advantage - shared learning, more like real life practical experiencedisadvantage - not well organized, expectations unclear
The group working is great in this class. We share thoughts freely and inspired each others a lot. I could not learn much without the group discussion and work

The Yellowstone group I worked with was amazing and it was one of the best group experiences I have ever had. Everyone pulled their weight/got their work done, and had a lot of fun with each other (i.e. we still have potlucks and get-togethers even after the class ended). Some of the most amazing/enlightening discussions I had this semester were with the members of this Yellowstone group.The Last Green Valley group was a disaster. There were some in the group who were not easy to get along with and who were very domineering/bossy. Some people did not pull their weight/ left it to the rest of the group to pick up the slack and didn't come to meetings/communicate with the rest of the group. It was an extremely frustrating and negative part of the class for me.

Group work is always challenging from a logistical standpoint. However, it is also a wonderful opportunity to discuss and bounce ideas back and forth. A lot of learning occurred in our group discussions as well.

It is always a worthwhile challenge to work with people from differing backgrounds. It was especially useful in a course such as this where it helps (at least it helps me) to talk about the concepts out loud with others.
It was a good group. People were willing to learn.
My group was valuable for understanding the ideas of the policy sciences and discuss our ideas. However, there were the typical group work problems of people not pulling their weight.
Some of my group members are irresponsible. I feel frustrated working with some of them
Advantage: consensus had to be reached and therefore a group helped to moderate and think through the ideasDisadvantage: scheduling could be a problem.
When groups were committed and individuals came to group work prepared, it worked well. Otherwise it was a pain.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be more active from the very beginning. This class is designed to be more self-organized than others.Ask questions! There are lots of abstract concepts in this class and you will never get it clear unless you ask.

Class lectures may be hard to sit through, but the ideas and content of the class are vital to anyone who wants to be an environmental manager. This was an eye-opening, life-changing class for me. If you are going to take the class, make sure you go on the spring break trip.
Take the course for 6 credits. The course and material presented in the classroom is excellent, but my greatest educational moments occurred on the field trip.
Take from the course what you need. Susan provides a buffet table of readings and ideas - you create your own adventure.
Roll with it.
Read the policy science book early and really understand it.
ask more questions, and try to use the idea we have been taught.
Talk to the professor. Do the reading. Ask a question if you're not understanding - perhaps ask the TA too.
Push for more discussions, and go on any field trips that are offered.
